journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Design and experimental control of an active–flexible tubular manipulator link

contrib-group.aff: IDMEC/Instituto Superior Técnico, Technical University of Lisbon, Lisboa, Portugal

author-notes.corresp: João C.P. Reis, IDMEC/Instituto Superior Técnico, Technical University of Lisbon, Avenida Rovisco Pais 1, 1049-001 Lisboa, Portugal. Email: reis@dem.ist.utl.pt

abstract.p: This article presents a study on a novel type of flexible links for robotic manipulators. These links incorporate adaptive materials in their construction, with the goal of controlling and attenuating vibrations that may occur during maneuvers due to high mechanical flexibility. The type of link under consideration has a tubular shape and incorporates piezoelectric actuators for simultaneous vibration control of bending and torsion modes. The design study addresses actuator placement and direction and is based on the directional properties of macro-fiber composite actuators. A vibration controller is also successfully designed and implemented. The experimental results validate the link and controller design and the directional actuation approach to vibration control of tubular structures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Initially driven by the specific needs of orbital manipulators, the study of robots featuring link flexibility has interested the research community throughout the last decades. The manipulation accuracy of robots operating at high speeds, or with large working volumes, or interacting with large contact forces, is significantly affected by flexibility (compliance) in their links and joints. Also, light structures tend to be weaker and more susceptible to bending deformation and vibrations. Therefore, to attain high performance, manipulator flexibility must be considered in all aspects of the design, including the capabilities of the flexible link itself. In early research, the usual approach was to control the link vibrations through joint actuators only. However, recent study has focused on the application of piezoelectric materials in the link as actuators for vibration control. The underlying principle is to use collocated sensor/actuator pairs distributed along the flexible link to cancel deformation, or actively increase the damping, of the link oscillations. This latter approach comprises knowledge from specialty fields such as modeling of active laminate structures, collocated vibration control, and control of flexible manipulators.

The first studies on vibration control of beam-like adaptive structures were carried out by Bailey and Hubbard (1985), and since then many other researchers have addressed this issue. Crawley and De Luis (1987) present a study on laminated beams featuring surface bonded as well as embedded actuators. Chandra and Chopra (1993) address the case of actuated composite open-section beams and experimentally evaluate rectangular cross-sectional beams with induced bending and twisting moments and axial forces. Benjeddou et al. (2000) explore the shear actuation mechanism of piezoelectric materials and compare this with the extension mechanism commonly used to induce bending in actuated beams. Cesnik and Palacios (2003) develop a numerical method to analyze the general, nonhomogeneous, nonisotropic, initially twisted, and curved beams, with embedded anisotropic piezocomposite actuators. In parallel with developments in active beam modeling and design, there was also an intensive study of control strategies for vibration suppression. In Bailey and Hubbard (1985), a linear constant-gain controller and a nonlinear constant-amplitude controller are compared, based on angular velocity feedback of the tip of the beam. Baz et al. (1987) study the application of the modified independent modal space control (MIMSC) to structures featuring piezoelectric actuation. Fanson and Caughey (1990) apply the positive position feedback (PPF) control strategy to the active vibration control of a cantilever beam. Poh and Baz (1990) propose a modal positive position feedback (MPPF) strategy to control the vibration of a complex flexible structure, and the results are further enhanced with a time sharing strategy to control a large number of modes with a small number of actuators. Kwak and Sciulli (1996) propose and evaluate a fuzzy logic controller for vibration suppression. Sugavanam et al. (1996) present a successful implementation of a linear quadratic Gaussian (LQG) controller on a cantilever beam with piezoelectric actuation. Petitjean and Legrain (1996) propose a frequency-shaped LQG controller and show it to be a viable approach to feedback control of lightly damped structures. Yang and Lee (1997) apply neural networks to system identification and vibration suppression of a smart structure. Smyser and Chandrashekhara (1997) use the linear quadratic Gaussian with loop transfer recovery (LQG/LTR) methodology to design a robust vibration controller for the structure, and then train and implement a system of neural networks to emulate the controller. Pota et al. (1999) propose a new type of collocated-tuned feedback controllers named resonant controllers. Varadarajan et al. (2000) investigate the direct application of an LQG/LTR-based multi-input multi-output robust vibration controller for a laminated composite beam. Song et al. (2002) present a robustness study of PPF controller performance in the presence of natural frequency uncertainty. Halim and Moheimani (2002) present the design of a controller to minimize the spatial H∞-norm of the closed-loop system.

Several applications of these actuation and control concepts to flexible-link robots have also been reported. Khorrami et al. (1993) use a decentralized control strategy featuring a simple proportional derivative (PD) controller for the joint, and a frequency-dependent linear quadratic regulator (LQR) with output feedback for the piezoelectric actuation of the link. Denoyer and Kwak (1996) compare the application of a PPF controller with that of an LQG controller. The PPF controller is composed of three independent PPF filters that target the first three modes of vibration. Choi et al. (1999) apply the quantitative feedback theory (QFT) to the design of robust controllers for the joint and piezoelectric actuators. Sun and Mills (2002) propose a decentralized control strategy using a PD controller for the joint, and a linear velocity feedback (L-type) controller for the link actuators. Moallem et al. (2004) investigate a strategy featuring multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) LQR control of both joints and active–flexible link, by feeding back the amplitude of only the first vibration mode of the link. Sun et al. (2004) present a more detailed study of the strategy proposed in Sun and Mills (2002) by examining stability and performance as a function of actuator placement, based on the analysis of mode shape functions. Shan et al. (2005) study the set-point and trajectory tracking control of a single-link flexible manipulator, featuring a PD controller with feedforward joint friction compensation for the joint and a multi-mode PPF controller for the link. Sun et al. (2005) propose a hybrid control algorithm, with a PD controller enhanced with a nonlinear differentiator to control the gross motion of the beam, and a L-type vibration controller for the lead zirconate titanate (PZT) actuators. Gurses et al. (2009) study the application of a fiber optic sensor to the control of the flexible link that allows for simultaneous angular (A-type) and linear (L-type) velocity feedbacks. The joint is also controlled by a PD-type controller.

With the exception of Chandra and Chopra (1993), where the quasi-static piezoelectrically induced twist of the beam is explored, the vast majority of these studies limit the number of elastic degrees of freedom of the flexible beam or link to a single bending displacement. In fact, due to the isotropic characteristics of common monolithic piezoelectric actuators, the generation of the shear forces necessary to induce twist is not straightforward. It is usually dependent on factors like the actuator aspect ratio, or the anisotropic elastic characteristics of the beam or bonding layer. The development of composite actuators like the active fiber composite (AFC; Bent et al. 1995) and the macro-fiber composite (MFC; Wilkie et al. 2000), with directional force induction characteristics, allowed for a more practical approach to torsional moment generation. Rodgers and Hagood (1997) present an application of AFC actuators to a rotor blade actuated in torsion, the actuators are embedded in the rotor blade profile laminate and the goal is to control the angle of attack of the blade. Park et al. (2001) study the application of MFC actuators to vibration control of inflatable structures. Choi et al. (2006) present an application of MFC actuators to vibration control of rotating beams, a subject that is further developed by Vadiraja and Sahasrabudhe (2009). Tarazaga et al. (2007) present an experimental application of active vibration control of an inflatable boom. Deraemaeker et al. (2007) develop detailed numerical models for MFC actuators and validate them against the identification results of an active composite boom. Neugebauer et al. (2005) apply MFC actuators to a tubular structure, for actuation of two elastic degrees of freedom in bending and one in torsion. In Neugebauer et al. (2005), the actuator distribution along the active cross-sectional perimeter, as well as the combination of four command signals to control only three individual degrees of freedom, is somewhat complex. In spite of its effectiveness, it is shown in Reis (2010) that comparable results can be achieved by at least one different active cross-sectional design, with the need of only three command signals.

In this article, the design, identification, and control of a flexible tubular structure with three significant elastic degrees of freedom (3D) is addressed. The link structure is defined a priori and consists of a polycarbonate (PCarb) tube with circular cross section and a steel plate acting as an offset tip mass. This geometry is intended to emulate the kind of inertial couplings that are present in the links of a serial chain manipulator, and that ultimately result in the excitation of vibration modes with coupled bending and torsion link displacements during the maneuver. The design task is therefore limited to determining sensor and actuator placement and orientation on the surface of the link. The goal is to provide the link with a collocated, or quasi-collocated, vibration control system acting on each of the three independent elastic degrees of freedom. To achieve this, first, the constitutive equations for an active laminate are formulated. Then, these equations are integrated over the circular cross-sectional perimeter to obtain equivalent beam forces and moments. The study proceeds with the determination of the ideal location of the sensing and active cross sections along the length of the link. This optimized placement is based on a modal analysis of the structure in free vibration. A reduced order model of the complete active–flexible link is then obtained directly from the prototype using classical system identification techniques. This reduced order model is used in the design of an MIMO LQG vibration controller that is implemented on the prototype. Finally, the whole approach is experimentally validated, and results from the vibration control experiment are presented.

sec.title: 3D active–flexible link design
sec.p: In this section, the design of the link actuation is described. The link itself is assumed as a tubular structure clamped at the base, and with a tip mass featuring an offset between the center of mass and the longitudinal axis of the link. Such an arrangement induces an inertial coupling, between bending and torsion displacements, which will be used in future research to emulate the type of mechanical loads that a serial chain manipulator link undergoes while maneuvering. The link reference coordinate system and the designation of the degrees of freedom that is used throughout this article are presented in Figure 1. The main reference is the plane that is defined by the longitudinal axis of the tube plus the center of mass of the tip plate. An elastic displacement in this plane is designated as in plane (InP). An elastic displacement in the plane perpendicular to InP that also contains the longitudinal axis of the link is called out of plane (OoP). Also, a rotation along the longitudinal axis of the link is called a torsional (Tor) displacement.

caption.p: Reference coordinate system and displacement designations for the link.

sec.p: In designing the link actuation, the starting point is a description of the actuation at the laminate level. This is followed by the design of the active cross section, or cross sections, of the link in order to maximize the induced beam forces and moments. Finally, the longitudinal placement of the actuators is addressed and optimized.

sec.title: Anisotropic laminate actuation
sec.p: The linear constitutive relationship describing the coupled behavior of the piezoelectric material is given as

where D is the electric displacement vector, ε the strain vector, σ the mechanical stress vector, and E the electrical field vector. The material constants C, e, and ϵ represent the stiffness matrix, the piezoelectrically induced stress, and the electrical permittivity, respectively. Equation (1) describes the direct piezoelectric effect that allows the use of piezoelectric materials as sensors, while equation (2) describes the inverse piezoelectric effect that allows the use of these materials as actuators. For thin-walled beams, the analysis at the laminate level can assume a state of plane stress, meaning that through-thickness stresses are relatively small compared to in-plane stresses. Relation (2) for a lamina with piezoelectric properties can be written as

where Q is the reduced stiffness matrix. The standard notation for composite materials is used and, accordingly, it is assumed that the polarization field is applied along fiber direction 1, instead of the conventional direction 3 found on piezoelectricity standards. If the lamina is placed at a certain angle θ relative to a fixed referential (x,y), the equivalent relation can be obtained by introducing a rotation matrix T and an auxiliary matrix R, leading to
where Q¯=T−1QRTR−1, and T and R are defined as

With equation (4), it is possible to write the basic elastic relations for a mixed passive/active laminate by considering E1=0 for passive laminas. The strain in a laminate can be represented as a function of mid-plane strain ε0 and curvature κ and is given by
where z is the distance from the centroidal line of the laminate, ε0 is the strain at z=0, and κ is the curvature of the laminate.
By integrating the stresses through the thickness, the membrane forces N and moments M can be calculated. Relations (4) and (5) can therefore be combined and written in matrix form as

where matrices A, B, and D are defined as for a passive laminate (Daniel and Ishai, 1994). The second term in equation (6) describes the piezoelectrically induced membrane forces and moments. For active laminas with constant through-thickness properties, it is given by
where np is the number of active laminas, I is the 3×3 identity matrix, and hk and z¯k represent the thickness and the centroidal coordinate of active lamina k, respectively.

When using a piezoelectric material as sensor, the governing equation is equation (1). Again, considering the pooling of the material to be along fiber direction 1, the transformed relation can be written as

sec.title: Induced beam forces and moments
sec.p: By integration of the piezoelectrically induced membrane forces and moments along the perimeter of a thin-walled tubular cross section, one can get the equivalent point forces and moments acting through the centroid of the cross section. These are convenient for the simplified analysis of a beam structure. According to the definition of the geometric variables and coordinate systems represented in Figure 2, these are given as

caption.p: Cross section of a thin-walled tubular link.

sec.p: For the case of a circular cross section, r = const. and ϑ=δ+π/2. Assuming that the contribution of the membrane moments Mp to the beam force resultants is negligible, it can be easily shown from equations (9) to (14) that it is possible to generate a torsion moment MZ_p and two bending moments MX_p and MY_p, each one individually decoupled from all other beam forces and moments. The required membrane actuation forces can be generated by directional piezoelectric actuators, like the MFC, if specific orientations of the actuators in the laminate are selected. However, for the special case of a single actuation layer, the MFCs will not be able to generate pure shear forces Nxy_p and, therefore, it will not be possible to generate a totally independent torsional moment MZ_p. In this case, a coupling will always exist between MZ_p and the longitudinal force FZ_p (a second force acting along the cross-sectional perimeter will also exist, but it is assumed irrelevant for the beam actuation analysis).

In Figure 3, two cross sections of an active link are represented: one designed to generate bending moments in both axis and the other to generate torsion. Both cross sections use a single active layer of MFC actuators bonded to the outside surface of the link. The laminates, the angles relative to the laminate axis x, and the electrical actuation signals are also represented. Three independent actuation signals (ch1, ch2, and ch3) are needed, to which the electrical potentials VOoP, VInP, and VTor are applied, corresponding to the actuation of each of the three relevant beam forces.

caption.p: Topology of active link cross sections.
MFC: macro-fiber composite.

sec.p: It is important to notice that choosing actuator orientation with a criteria based on the excitation of the three independent elastic degrees of freedom of the link is a design option, which is due to the fact that a robot link is usually subjected to varying boundary conditions at the tip. A formal, and simultaneous, optimization of both orientation and placement of the actuators should be performed, if a pattern and range of boundary conditions can be identified for normal operation of the robot.

Sensing of the strains associated with elastic displacements in each degree of freedom is a dual problem to that of actuation. Strains measured along the lines where the InP and the OoP planes intersect the surface of the link can be related to the local beam curvature and cross-sectional rotation, and hence to the three degrees of freedom. This is achieved by a linear combination of sensor signals. In Figure 4, the instrumented cross section, the laminate, and the electrical signals are represented.

caption.p: Topology of sensor-instrumented cross section.

sec.p: The three independent electric charge signals that are directly correlated to the three degrees of freedom can be obtained from the following expressions

Notice that STor is defined in such a way that it makes it sensitive to displacements along the longitudinal axis of the link. However, this degree of freedom is assumed to be negligible in the link vibration analysis.

sec.title: Longitudinal actuator placement
sec.p: In order to optimize the longitudinal placement of sensing and actuating cross sections, a modal analysis of the link in free vibration is performed with the help of a finite-element software, and the modal strains related to the spatial solution of each mode of vibration are evaluated. The material and dimensional characteristics of the link used in this study are given in Tables 2 and 3 in Appendix 1. The first six mode frequencies and respective mode shapes are presented in Figure 5.

caption.p: Mode shapes of the link without piezoelectric actuators: (a) mode 1, frequency: 3.41 Hz; (b) mode 2, frequency: 3.46 Hz; (c) mode 3, frequency: 22.07 Hz; (d) mode 4, frequency: 26.22 Hz; (e) mode 5, frequency: 45.80 Hz; and (f) mode 6, frequency: 63.87 Hz.

sec.p: The optimization of laminate design at the actuation level is based on maximizing the work done by the piezoelectrically induced forces. The work per unit area produced by the membrane forces in a laminate under plane stress conditions is given as
where u¯ is the average energy density over the total laminate thickness h, and the elements of [(ε0)TκT] are the mid-plane extensions and curvatures.

Considering a laminate in free vibration, one can approximate the extensions and curvatures by an infinite series of its modal components with amplitude νj and spatial solution [(ε0)TκT]j, and equation (18) can be rewritten as
Assuming that the membrane forces are exclusively induced by the piezoelectric active laminas, the energy contribution of the piezoelectric actuators to vibration mode j is given by

It is possible to conclude from equation (19) that the influence of the actuator over a specific vibration mode j is maximized if the orientation and placement of the actuator coincide with the maximum principal strains of the mode shape. Since the actuator orientation was already established in the previous section, actuation influence can be maximized instead by choosing a longitudinal position where the absolute value of [(ε0)TκT]j is maximum along the direction of actuation.
In the modal analysis of the link, the distribution over the length of the longitudinal and shear strains for the first six modes of vibration was calculated.

The strain values from nodes belonging to planes InP and OoP were linearly combined by expressions (15) to (17) in order to get strain values correlated to the three relevant elastic degrees of freedom. In Figure 6, the distribution of these strain values is represented, as well as a description of the composition of the mode shapes in terms of elastic displacements of the beam.

caption.p: Combined strain levels for InP, OoP, and Tor displacements. (a) mode 1, InP; (b) mode 2, OoP + Tor; (c) mode 3, OoP + Tor; (d) mode 4, InP; (e) mode 5, OoP + Tor; and (f) mode 6, InP.

sec.p: The results of the analysis show that mode shapes 1, 4, and 6 cause much larger strains correlated to displacements in InP than to displacements in OoP (≈0) and Tor (≈0). Also, in modes 2, 3, and 5, the strains correlated to displacements in OoP and Tor are always coupled and are much larger than strains correlated to displacements in InP (≈0). These results are explained by the position of the tip mass, which is located in the InP plane and with an offset distance from the OoP plane, thus causing an inertial coupling between displacements in OoP and Tor.

Another important observation is that strains correlated to displacements in Tor are approximately constant along the length of the link for these modes of vibration. This means that torsion sensors and actuators can be placed freely along the length of the beam, without significant change to their sensitivity or influence coefficients. Also, collocation characteristics of the torsional sensor/actuator pair are preserved, regardless of the longitudinal distance between them. It is also possible to conclude from Figure 6 that the longitudinal position that maximizes the influence of the OoP actuators is near the clamping point of the link, because it is where the maximum strain values occur for modes 2, 3, and 5. For the case of InP actuators, the influence over mode 4 can be maximized by placing them near the tip mass rather than the clamping point. However, the maximum strain values are close to each other, and for modes 1 and 6, the best position is also near the clamping point of the link, and so this is the preferred location.

The gray areas inside the axes in Figure 6 represent the final longitudinal position chosen for the actuators and sensors. From the clamping point (left) to the tip (right), one finds, respectively, the link segment actuated by the OoP + InP actuators, the link segment with sensors, and the link segment actuated by the Tor actuators. For practical reasons, the cross section of the beam used for sensing is not the same used for actuation. However, it can be seen in Figure 6 that they are close enough so that a quasi-collocated beam vibration control loop can be implemented for the first six modes.

sec.title: Final link configuration
sec.p: The final configuration of the link is represented in Figure 7, while a detail of the link instrumentation is shown in Figure 8.

caption.p: Active–flexible tubular manipulator link.
MFC: macro-fiber composite.
Detail of instrumentation placement and dimensions for 3D actuation (all distances in millimeter).

sec.p: The arrows in Figure 8 represent the fiber direction of the piezoelectric material. MFC actuators from Smart Material Corp., model M8528-P1, were used as actuators for InP and OoP degrees of freedom (fibers aligned along the length of the link)—model M8528-F1 was used as actuator for the Tor degree of freedom (fibers at an angle of −45° with the direction of length) and model M2814-P1 was used as sensor (the MFC itself is bonded at an angle of −45° with the direction of length).

sec.title: Frequency domain identification
sec.p: The Levy method is a classical method of single-input, single-output (SISO) system identification from experimental results in frequency domain. The approach is to estimate the parameters of a model with a known structure through the minimization of the mean square error between the frequency response of the model and the experimental data. One of the known characteristics of this method is that the quality of the approximation increases with frequency, and so the model becomes better adjusted for high-frequency behavior. An alternative to this formulation was presented in Valério et al. (2008) that automatically adjusts a vector of weight components associated with frequency, thus resulting in a more balanced approximation of frequency response along a desired bandwidth.

This modified Levy method allows for a white-box step-by-step approach to system identification of the link, which is convenient to check the mode shape displacement predicted by the finite-element model. The model is first obtained in transfer matrix form, element by element, considering three inputs (the InP, OoP, and Tor sets of actuators) and four outputs (the independent sensors), as given by
where G^ij has the general form

This form implies that each transfer function G^ij(s) has its own order nij, while all have relative order equal to 0. The elements of zij and pij are the input j to output i zeros and poles, respectively, and kij is the gain factor. The results of the identification procedure are presented in Figures 9 to 11. In order to increase the efficiency of the method, the order nij of each particular SISO model was established as the double of the number of relevant resonant peaks detected in the experimental frequency response and is indicated at the top of each figure.

caption.p: Frequency identification results from input OoP to output: (a) s1, (b) s2, (c) s3, and (d) s4.
Frequency identification results from input InP to output: (a) s1, (b) s2, (c) s3, and (d) s4.
Frequency identification results from input Tor to output: (a) s1, (b) s2, (c) s3, and (d) s4.

sec.p: In almost every input/output relation, the modified Levy method was able to produce a reasonable adjustment of the models to the experimental curves. The only exception was the phase curve from input InP to output s3 represented in Figure 10(c). However, in this case, it is most likely that the experimental curve itself is corrupted, due to the difficulty in evaluating the phase of a response with near zero amplitude. Both registered discrepancies have a phase shift of 360°, which seems to support this interpretation.
The values obtained for the natural frequencies are presented in Table 1. They are helpful for the interpretation of the experimental magnitude curves.

caption.p: Estimated natural frequencies.

sec.p: In Figure 9, the relative influence of the OoP actuators over the several modes of vibration can be observed. For all the sensors, the larger peaks correspond to the frequencies of modes 2, 3, and 5. This was to be expected, since these are the modes that theoretically have only OoP + Tor displacement. In practice, however, smaller peaks can be detected at the frequencies of modes 4 and 6 that are only expected to have InP displacement; these are probably due to the tolerances used in the actual construction of the link. In Figures 10 and 11, the same analysis can be made for the InP and Tor actuation. In Figure 10, the larger peaks occur at the frequencies of modes 1, 4, and 6, meaning that the InP actuator revealed greater influence over the modes featuring InP displacement. In Figure 11, the only visible peaks correspond to modes 2, 3, and 5, which are the modes featuring Tor displacement. One can conclude that the intended individual excitation of the elastic degrees of freedom by the OoP and InP actuators may not be totally achieved, due to practical implementation issues, but that the built prototype clearly approximates this behavior.

Further physical interpretation of the identification results in this form is not straightforward, because the outputs are the individual sensors rather than the linear combinations SOoP, SInP, and STor, and therefore local deformation effects are present. One could perhaps expect that the gain curves corresponding to sensor s1 would resemble the ones corresponding to sensor s3 (and the same for sensors s2 and s4), due to their relative position along the section perimeter. However, it should be noticed that the local deformations are not exactly symmetrical due to the offset tip mass, and that this has the effect of displacing some of the transmission zeros. This phenomena can be easily observed in Figure 11, by comparing Figure 11(a) to (c) and Figure 11(b) to (d), in the vicinity of the frequencies of modes 2 and 5.

sec.title: MIMO model
sec.p: In order to obtain a representative MIMO model from the independent transfer matrix elements, some details must be taken into consideration. The matrix should be able to be represented in the form

where N(s) is the matrix of the numerators of each G^ij(s), d(s) is the characteristic polynomial that has roots related to the natural frequencies of the mechanical structure and is common to every element of G^(s), and n is the order of d(s). Since the transfer matrix identification was performed element by element, it is expectable that small differences arise between the identified pole locations due to noise, and so the locations of such poles must be averaged. The final values for the roots of d(s) are presented in Appendix 2 in Table 4. The values for the roots and gain of each element of N(s) are presented in Tables 5 to 8. The MIMO model of the active–flexible link is completely defined by these parameters.

sec.title: LQG control
sec.p: The transfer matrix model can be easily converted to a state-space representation in the form of equation (23), which is more convenient for MIMO controller design. Once in state-space form, the sensor signals can be linearly combined by expressions (15) to (17), so that the collocated output signals are directly obtained from the model. For this representation, the input and output vectors are defined by
The optimal controller that minimizes the cost functional

under the feedback control law u=−K~x is the well-known LQR (Lewis and Syrmos, 1995). State estimation through a state observer is usually needed for feed-back and so the actually implemented feedback law is u=−K~x^, where the estimated state vector is given by

A minimum variance observer (Kalman–Bucy filter) assumes that the errors between the system dynamic and the model dynamic (wn), and the noise associated with output measurement (vn), can both be approximated by white noise. Formally, the inclusion of these terms in the system model given by equation (23) leads to the following
By defining covariances W=E[H~wnwnTH~T] and V=E[vnvnT], the Kalman gain is given by
where Z~ is the covariance matrix of the estimation error, that is, the solution of the Riccati equation
The Kalman gain used in the experimental system state observer was designed using the following assumptions
The state feedback loop is represented in Figure 12.

caption.p: Feedback control loop with state observer.

sec.title: Simulation and experimental results
sec.p: In order to test the proposed approach to actuation and controller design, an experiment was conceived where the elastic modes of the link are disturbed by a pulse signal applied to all the system inputs simultaneously. In the vibration control experiments, the controller is activated only after the pulse signal is removed. The applied pulse has an amplitude of 500 V and a duration of 0.1 s, and the controller is activated 0.3 s after the removal of the pulse signal. The resulting time responses for the noncontrolled and controlled cases are shown in Figure 13.

caption.p: Simulation results for the controlled and noncontrolled cases in response to a pulse perturbation in the system inputs: (a) Sensor output voltage and (b) Actuator input voltage.
Sen.: Sensor; Act.: Actuator.

sec.p: In Figure 13(a), it is possible to verify that the noncontrolled oscillations are sustained in time beyond the 2.0 s limit imposed to the simulation. Both the noncontrolled and the controlled responses are perfectly coincident until the simulation time reaches t=0.5s, which is the moment when the controller is activated. From that moment on the controlled response is quickly attenuated and is practically eliminated by time t=1.0s, that is, within a settling time of 0.5s from the start of the control action. Notice that the presence of low-frequency oscillations in the signal of the Tor sensor is due to the coupling between OoP displacement and Tor displacement in mode 2. This can be confirmed by comparing the low-frequency components of the signals of the OoP and the Tor sensors. In Figure 13(b), the actuator signals in the controlled case are presented. The perturbation pulse, and the moment when the controller is turned on, are both clearly recognizable and apart. One can also see that the actuation signal was limited to the interval [−500,500]V in all three inputs, which is desirable to the practical implementation of this experiment.

The experimental results are presented in Figure 14 together with the simulation results. The uncontrolled system response to the initial excitation is represented in Figure 14(a), where one seems to find good agreement between predicted and measured results. There is an increasing phase shift between experimental and simulated oscillations that is probably due to small errors in the identification of natural frequencies. The system response with controlled vibrations is represented in Figure 14(b). Good agreement is found in general between simulation and experimental results, although the oscillations of the third mode seem to persist a little more than what was predicted in simulation. This experiment shows that the implemented active vibration controller is able to produce a strong attenuation of the system oscillations in all the three degrees of freedom considered in the design. For completion, the comparison between the experimental response of the system and the response reconstructed from the estimated states is represented in Figure 15(a), while Figure 15(b) shows the experimental and the predicted curves for the actuator control signals.

caption.p: Experimental and predicted system response: (a) noncontrolled case and (b) controlled case.
Sen.: Sensor; Act.: Actuator.
Experimental and simulation results: (a) observer response and (b) control signal.
Sen.: Sensor; Act.: Actuator.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article presents a study in design, identification, and experimental control of a novel type of robotic manipulator links. These links feature high mechanical flexibility and incorporate piezoelectric actuation for simultaneous vibration control of torsion and bending modes (3D).

The design task that is presented is focused on the piezoelectric actuation of the link and on the vibration controller. In order to cope with the wide range of boundary conditions that a manipulator link is subjected to while maneuvering, the actuation design is based on a criteria of independent actuation of each relevant elastic degree of freedom. The actuation study is carried out from the laminate level of the tubular wall to the optimization of the location along the length of the link. The design criteria takes into consideration the maximization of the work done by the actuators, the maximization of sensitivity of the sensors, and the desirable quasi-collocated characteristic of the sensor/actuator signal pairs for each degree of freedom.

A reduced order model of the active–flexible link is obtained through system identification in the frequency domain. A white-box model approach is followed, in order to allow for a step-by-step identification procedure and an intuitive interpretation of the identification results. These results indicate that a perfectly independent actuation of the elastic degrees of freedom may be difficult to achieve in practice; however, the results obtained in the prototype approximate this behavior.

The reduced order model is then used in the synthesis of an LQG controller for vibration attenuation purposes. A control experiment is first simulated, where the link is disturbed from its equilibrium position by pulse-shaped input signals applied to the actuators, and then the residual vibrations are attenuated by the control system. The simulation results show that the settling time of the controlled system response is much smaller than the settling time of the response in the noncontrolled case.

Experimental results confirm the performance of the controlled system that was predicted in simulation and, furthermore, they validate the design and the overall concept of application of directional piezoelectric actuation to vibration control of tubular structures with several elastic degrees of freedom.
